critique: This executive order establishes a National Defense Executive Reserve, composed of civilians trained for federal government executive positions during emergencies. It directs the Office of Defense Mobilization to administer the program, coordinate agency activities, and set recruitment/training standards. Other agencies can assist in maintaining rosters and developing training. Designated department heads can establish Executive Reserve units. Reservists' activities are limited to training and exempt from certain conflict-of-interest laws. The Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization reports to the President. The order seems to expand executive power by creating a reserve of trained civilians for use during emergencies, potentially bypassing standard hiring procedures. It also centralizes power in the executive branch through the Office of Defense Mobilization. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, impact on civil liberties, economic regulation, or social inclusion. Therefore, most axes should be neutral, with a slight positive score for executive power and federalism.
